questions.text: What is the usual position of the Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Supranuclear 

Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. Serous acinar cells are generally found in pancreas and the submandibular salivary glands.

questions.text: In the homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Increased preciseness of movements 

A homunculus is a neurological map that depicts the relative size of different body parts based on their sensitivity in the sensory cortex. Areas with more sensory receptors (like the fingertips) have a larger representation on the homunculus, indicating greater precision of movement and sensation in those areas

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Connexons are involved in electrical synapse

In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next cell. The transmission in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlike chemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity

questions.text: In a 100-m dash, most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Phosphocreatine 

In a 100-m dash that takes 10 s, 85% of the energy consumed is derived anaerobically by phosphocreatine, which is hydrolyzed to creatine and phosphate groups with the release of considerable energy.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Inferior olivary nucleus 

The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

questions.text: Integrin connects with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Fibronectin 

Integrin connects with fibronectin. Integrins are transmembrane glycoproteins (integral proteins) that allow cells to attach to extracellular matrix constituents such as laminin, fibronectin and collagen. It helps in linking the intracellular cytoskeleton functionally and structurally with the outside world.

questions.text: The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Burst forming units 

BFU is the earliest stage of hematopoiesis where erythropoietin (EPO) acts Under the influence of EPO, both BFU and CFU grow in semisolid culture media and give rise to colonies of well-hemoglobinized erythroblasts. Erythroid burst-forming unit (BFU-E) is the most primitive single lineage committed erythroid progenitor. In addition to EPO, they form the subpopulation of Erythroid Colony Forming Units (CFU-E). CFU is derived from burst-forming units

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Secondary active transport

Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. On the basolateral side, there is active transport of sodium ions out of the cell into the interstitial fluid. This depletes sodium inside the cell. Because of this Na+ concentration difference, more Na+ binds to the SGLT on the luminal side. This increases the affinity of SGLT for glucose and glucose binds to it.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Leptin 

The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin. It now appears that leptin may be the link between body weight and puberty. Leptin is a satietyproducing hormone secreted by adipocytes. High leptin levels reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Prolactin and growth hormone 

Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted mainly on prolactin and growth hormone.

questions.text: Factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

All of the above

Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

choices.text: Degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in primordial germ cells of males

questions.text: Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

All of the above

Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in all of the above. 11B-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase inactivates glucocorticoids in renal tubular cells, preventing actions through the mineralocorticoid receptor. During development, degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 prevents the primordial germ cells in the male from entering meiosis, which occurs in the female ovary

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Ureteric stone 

Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Following ureteral obstruction, there is a progressive fall in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons. All other factors given in options increase the GFR.

questions.text: In negative feedback, feedback gain of infinity is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Blood volume control by kidney 

In negative feedback, feedback gain of infinity could be seen in blood volume control by the kidney. When the blood volume falls below the equilibrium, the renal—body fluid mechanism causes the blood volume returns back to the equilibrium point resulting in zero error and hence the gain of kidney in its ability to regulate blood volume is infinity. The degree of effectiveness with which a regulatory system maintains constant conditions is determined by the gain of the negative feedback system

choices.text: Binding to beta subunit of Hb

questions.text: 2,3-BPG causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Binding to beta subunit of Hb 

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by binding to the beta subunit of Hb. 2,3 BPG is formed from glycolysis. It is found in high amounts in red blood cells and in trace amounts in most other cells. 2,3 BPG facilitates increased oxygen delivery by reducing the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Thyroxine 

Thyroxine hormone act by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors. All other hormones mentioned in the options bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Convergence 

Convergence in neuroscience refers to the situation where multiple neurons converge onto a single neuron, meaning one neuron is receiving input from many other neurons. In this scenario, a single neuron is receiving signals from 400 sensory neurons, demonstrating clear convergence.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Gate control theory 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is a pain-relief technique that aligns with the gate control theory of pain. It uses surface electrodes to stimulate sensory nerve fibers near the injury, primarily activating Aa and Abeta fibers. According to the gate control theory, non-painful sensory input can modulate pain signals at the spinal cord level. Sensory information from a given dermatome travels to the dorsal horn, where pain signals are transmitted through A-delta and C fibers. In contrast, Abeta fibers convey tactile sensations such as touch and pressure, and A-alpha fibers carry proprioceptive information.
Rewritten passage
Activation of large-diameter A-beta and A-alpha fibers can suppress pain signaling in the spinal cord. This suppression is believed to occur through local lateral inhibition of interneurons within the dorsal horn. The gate control theory posits that this modulatory effect takes place at the substantia gelatinosa, a key region in the dorsal horn that acts as a gate to regulate pain transmission.

questions.text: A 60-year old patient visits for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Arterial wall compliance 

Pulse pressure rises with age because the arteries become less compliant. As people age, systolic blood pressure tends to increase while diastolic pressure often declines after around 60 years due to greater arterial stiffness. Together, these changes lead to an increased pulse pressure.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Exosome 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotic cells occurs, in part, via exosomes. Over the past decade, a diverse group of secreted vesicles, collectively known as extracellular vesicles, has been characterized. These vesicles are now recognized as important mediators of cell–cell communication and are thought to play significant roles in both normal physiology and disease processes.
